data.title: Top teens boxing in Junior Olympic National Championships this week in Mobile
data.meta_description: None of the 202 competitors coming to Mobile for USA Boxing's 42nd Junior Olympic National Championships is from Alabama. But for three of the fighters, the Arthur R. Outlaw Convention Center will feel be as comfortable as home.
data.text:
junior olympic boxing.jpg

A bout during USA Boxing's 2012 Junior Olympic National Championships at the Arthur R. Outlaw Convention Center in Mobile, Ala., on June 19, 2012. The boxing tournament returns to the Port City on Wednesday through Saturday. (Press-Register file)

MOBILE, Alabama - None of the 202 competitors coming to Mobile for USA Boxing's 42nd Junior Olympic National Championships is from Alabama. But for three of the fighters, the Arthur R. Outlaw Convention Center will feel as comfortable as home.

That's because Shakur Stevenson of Newark, N.J., Ruben Villa of Salinas, Calif., and Akemi Collezo of San Antonio, Texas, won Junior Olympic national titles in last year's tournament in Mobile.

The 2013 Junior Olympic National Championships will be contested in Mobile for the third straight year from Wednesday through Saturday. The tournament features 15- and 16-year-old boxers from 36 states and the District of Columbia.

The field includes boys and girls fighting in 23 divisions. The competitors are a mix of winners from 14 regional tournaments, reigning champs and Junior World Team Open winners.

This week's tournament features 15 champions from the Junior World Team Open, which was held in Reno, Nev., in January. Despite its name, all the fighters in that tournament were from the United States. However, the tourney did serve as a qualifier for international teams.

Stevenson in light bantamweight, light flyweight Daniel Gonzalez of Moreno Valley, Calif., and heavyweight Pano Tiatia of St. George, Utah, went from the Junior World Team Open ring to championships at the Victory Day Tournament held in Uman, Ukraine, in May. All three are coming to Mobile, as are pinweight Jordan White of Waldorf, Md., and lightweight Keoni Adric Jr. of Haleiwa, Hawaii, who won silver medals at Victory Day.

Three female fighters - pinweight Caitlin Orosco of Anaheim, Calif., bantamweight Jessica Galvez of Reno and lightweight Iesha Kenney of Alexandria, Va., -- did something similar, following their Junior World Team Open championships by taking titles at the Pirkka Tournament in Finland in May. Orosco was named the outstanding boxer at the international event. All three are scheduled to fight in Mobile this week.

Stevenson won his Junior Olympic title as a flyweight. He's moved up a weight class, as has Villa, who's gone from light bantamweight to bantamweight. Collezo returns to defend his flyweight title.

USA Boxing is the national governing body for Olympic-style boxing and is a member of the International Amateur Boxing Association and the U.S. Olympic Committee. Boxers competing in Mobile this week could wind up representing the nation in the 2016 Summer Games in Rio de Janeiro. Claressa Shields won in Mobile in 2011 before earning the first gold medal in women's boxing in the Olympic Games in 2012 in London.

Preliminary bouts are scheduled at the convention center from noon to 4 p.m. and 6 to 10 p.m. on Wednesday. The quarterfinals are scheduled for noon to 4 p.m. and 6 to 10 p.m. Thursday. The semifinals follow the same schedule on Friday. The championship fights are set from 2 to 6 p.m. Saturday.

Tickets will be available at the door for $12 per day. Four-day passes can be purchased for $40. For more information about tickets, contact the Mobile Sports Authority at 251-725-1794.
